item.title: McCain’s Surgery Will Delay Senate Votes on Health Care Bill
item.media:description: Senator John McCain in April. He has been noncommittal in his comments on the bill to repeal the Affordable Care Act.
item.description: With John McCain’s absence, Republicans would have only 49 votes to move ahead with the legislation; all Democrats and the two independent senators oppose it.
item.dc:creator: ROBERT PEAR
item.category: Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)

item.title: In Clash Over Health Bill, a Growing Fear of ‘Junk Insurance’
item.media:description: Julie Arkison, a self-employed horseback-riding instructor, at her farm in Saline, Mich. She said the insurance plan she had before the Affordable Care Act ended up costing her thousands of dollars when she needed hip surgery.
item.media:credit: Laura McDermott for The New York Times
item.description: The Republicans’ proposal to overturn Obamacare could allow insurers to sell bare-bones plans that fail to pay for what is now deemed essential medical care.
item.dc:creator: REED ABELSON
item.category: Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)

item.title: Trump Goes on Attack as Russia Revelations Appear to Take Toll
item.media:description: President Trump on Saturday at Trump National Golf Club during the United States Women’s Open in Bedminster, N.J.
item.media:credit: Eric Thayer for The New York Times
item.description: During a weekend of watching golf in New Jersey, the president used Twitter to defend his son and excoriate Hillary Clinton and the news media.
item.dc:creator: MARK LANDLER
item.category: Russian Interference in 2016 US Elections and Ties to Trump Associates

item.title: Soviet Veteran Who Met With Trump Jr. Is a Master of the Dark Arts
item.media:description: Rinat Akhmetshin at a House Foreign Affairs Committee hearing last summer on United States policy toward Russia.
item.description: Rinat Akhmetshin, a gregarious, fast-talking man with a sharp sense of humor, has often warned his friends and contacts: “Nothing is secure.”
item.dc:creator: ANDREW HIGGINS and ANDREW E. KRAMER
item.category: Russian Interference in 2016 US Elections and Ties to Trump Associates

item.title: Huge Manafort Payment Reflects Murky Ukraine Politics
item.media:description: Paul Manafort on the floor of the Republican National Convention in Cleveland in 2016.
item.description: How did an organization that reported spending of less than $15 million over two years pay Donald J. Trump’s former campaign chairman $17 million?
item.dc:creator: ANDREW E. KRAMER
item.category: Russian Interference in 2016 US Elections and Ties to Trump Associates

item.title: Trump’s Re-Election Campaign Doubles Its Spending on Legal Fees
item.media:description: Committees focused on President Trump’s re-election spent nearly $200,000 on branded merchandise between April and June.
item.description: The committees devoted to Mr. Trump’s 2020 campaign spent nearly $700,000 on legal fees in the second quarter, according to reports filed Saturday.
item.dc:creator: KENNETH P. VOGEL and RACHEL SHOREY
item.category: Russian Interference in 2016 US Elections and Ties to Trump Associates

item.title: After a Harrowing Flight From U.S., Refugees Find Refuge in Canada
item.media:description: Razak Iyal, 35, center left, and Seidu Mohammed, 24, center right, volunteering at the Canadian Muslim Women’s Institute in Winnipeg.
item.media:credit: Aaron Vincent Elkaim for The New York Times
item.description: Two Ghanaian refugees lost all but a single thumb to frostbite while fleeing the United States. Six months later, they’ve both been accepted in Canada.
item.dc:creator: CATHERINE PORTER

item.title: Donald Trump Jr., Macron, Senate Republicans: Your Weekend Briefing
item.media:credit: Sam Hodgson for The New York Times
item.description: Here’s what you need to know about the week’s top stories.
item.dc:creator: MAYA SALAM and HEATHER CASEY

item.title: Asia and Australia Edition: Roger Federer, Turkey, Donald Trump Jr.: Your Monday Briefing
item.description: Here’s what you need to know to start your day.
item.dc:creator: CHARLES McDERMID

item.title: At a Luxury Complex in India, the Maids and the Madams Go to War
item.media:description: A dispute between a maid and her employer ignited a riot at the Mahagun Moderne complex in Noida, India.
item.media:credit: Poras Chaudhary for The New York Times
item.description: A dispute between a maid and her employer led to a full-blown riot, an unusual boiling over of resentment between rich and poor in India.
item.dc:creator: SUHASINI RAJ and ELLEN BARRY

item.title: Roger Federer Wins Record-Breaking Eighth Wimbledon Title
item.media:description: Roger Federer, who turns 36 next month, is the oldest man to win the Wimbledon singles title in the Open era, which began in 1968.
item.description: Federer defeated Marin Cilic in straight sets, making him the man with the most singles titles at the tournament, and the oldest man to win it in the Open era.
item.dc:creator: CHRISTOPHER CLAREY

item.title: Whimsical Urban Debris as Art in Detroit
item.description: More than 30 years ago, Tyree Guyton began transforming the blighted street he grew up on. Now, he is dismantling a portion of what is known as the Heidelberg Project to begin something new.

item.title: Your Daily Mini Crossword
item.description: Solve a bite-size crossword in just a few minutes.

item.title: What Happens After Prison? This.
item.description: The Times, in collaboration with the PBS series “Frontline,” followed 10 recently released inmates struggling to succeed on the outside.

item.title: She’s His Rock. His Parole Officer Won’t Let Him See Her.
item.description: As prison rolls drop and the number of parolees increases, a Connecticut man learns that getting out of prison is not the same as being free.
item.dc:creator: SHAILA DEWAN

item.title: Cardinals on Opposite Sides of the Hudson Reflect Two Paths of Catholicism
item.media:description: Cardinal Joseph W. Tobin, top, in May before a service welcoming gay, lesbian, bisexual and transgender Catholics at the Cathedral Basilica of the Sacred Heart in Newark.
item.media:credit: Bryan Anselm for The New York Times
item.description: Cardinal Joseph W. Tobin of Newark tends toward the progressive spirit of Pope Francis; Cardinal Timothy M. Dolan of New York hews toward Pope Benedict’s conservative views.
item.dc:creator: SHARON OTTERMAN

item.title: After N.F.L. Concussion Settlement, Feeding Frenzy of Lawyers and Lenders
item.media:description: Walter Carter, who played for the Raiders and the Buccaneers, has heard from at least a dozen companies pitching services.
item.media:credit: Eve Edelheit for The New York Times
item.description: The possibility of large payouts to former players, many with cognitive ailments from hits to the head, attracts offers of help with claims, for a cut.
item.dc:creator: KEN BELSON

item.title: How Andy Serkis Plays a Talking Chimp, Believably
item.description: Andy Serkis (famously known as Gollum in “The Lord of the Rings”) reprises his role as the talking chimpanzee Caesar in "War for the Planet of the Apes."
item.category: War for the Planet of the Apes (Movie)

item.title: Andy Serkis on the Ending of ‘War for the Planet of the Apes’
item.media:description: Mr. Serkis wearing performance-capture sensors on the set of “War for the Planet of the Apes,” directed by Matt Reeves.
item.description: The actor says he wasn’t surprised when he read the script because it had been planned for a few years. But the movie was shot out of order, and that was difficult.
item.dc:creator: ROSLYN SULCAS
item.category: War for the Planet of the Apes (Movie)

item.title: ‘Planet of the Apes’ Arrives to Ho-Hum Ticket Sales
item.media:description: A scene from “War for the Planet of the Apes,” the third film in the franchise.
item.description: The third film in the ‘Apes’ franchise took in $56.5 million at the North American box office in its first weekend, a sluggish start.
item.dc:creator: BROOKS BARNES
item.category: War for the Planet of the Apes (Movie)

item.title: Tehran's Turn | Part 1: Iran Dominates in Iraq After U.S. ‘Handed the Country Over’
item.media:description: Members of the Popular Mobilization Forces, a mostly Shiite militia group, at their post at the Iraqi border with Syria.
item.media:credit: Sergey Ponomarev for The New York Times
item.description: The United States spent more than $1 trillion and lost about 4,500 troops in the effort to make Iraq the cornerstone of a Western-facing Middle East. But today, Iran’s influence is paramount.
item.dc:creator: TIM ARANGO

item.title: Maryam Mirzakhani, Only Woman to Win a Fields Medal, Dies at 40
item.media:description: Maryam Mirzakhani was awarded a Fields Medal in 2014. Many Iranian newspapers covered her death in front-page articles, ​some of which showed recent photographs of her without her head covered.
item.media:credit: Stanford University, via European Pressphoto Agency
item.description: Dr. Mirzakhani, a mathematician at Stanford University, was the only woman and only Iranian ever to win what is often described as the Nobel Prize of mathematics.
item.dc:creator: KENNETH CHANG

item.title: Arson Suspected in Fire in China That Killed at Least 22
item.media:description: The building where a deadly fire broke out early on Sunday in Jiangsu Province, China.
item.description: A suspect was arrested in the blaze at a two-story house used as a workers’ dormitory in Jiangsu Province.
item.dc:creator: CHRIS BUCKLEY

item.title: U.S. Journalist Found Alive in Congo; 5 Others Are Killed
item.description: Five park rangers were found dead and a female journalist was in good condition in the Okapi Wildlife Reserve after going missing during a militia attack.
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: ‘Doctor Who’ Breaks the Mold With Female Lead
item.media:description: Jodie Whittaker is the next star of the BBC’s “Doctor Who.”
item.description: Jodie Whittaker will be the first woman to play the Doctor, taking over from Peter Capaldi, the BBC said.
item.dc:creator: ANDREW R. CHOW

item.title: Chicago Airport Security Officers to Shed ‘Police’ Label After United Airlines Dragging Episode
item.media:description: Video still images of a United Airlines passenger, Dr. David Dao, being removed from a flight in Chicago in April.
item.media:credit: Audra D. Bridges, via Associated Press
item.description: A report on the April treatment of Dr. David Dao says that new measures will limit the authority of Chicago’s airport security officers to board airplanes.
item.dc:creator: MATT STEVENS

item.title: Erdogan and Supporters Stage Rally on Anniversary of Failed Coup
item.media:description: President Recep Tayyip Erdogan addressing a huge crowd at the presidential palace in Ankara on Sunday, where he flew after a rally in Istanbul. He is seen as a threat to many democratic freedoms, but his supporters argue that he has upheld the civil rights that are important to them.
item.description: The event this weekend was the centerpiece of an elaborate day of pageantry that implicitly placed the president as the hero.
item.dc:creator: PATRICK KINGSLEY
item.category: Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat

item.title: Comey’s Writing a Book, and Publishers Are Eager to Pay Big Money for It
item.media:description: James B. Comey has been meeting with editors and publishers in New York. His book is expected to go to auction this week.
item.description: Mr. Comey’s book, which will address his run-ins with President Trump and other moments in his career, is expected to go to auction this coming week.
item.dc:creator: ALEXANDRA ALTER
item.category: Russian Interference in 2016 US Elections and Ties to Trump Associates

item.title: Brazilian Court Dismisses False-Report Case Against Ryan Lochte
item.media:description: The American swimmer Ryan Lochte had been charged with filing a false robbery report last year.
item.description: Lochte had been charged with filing a false robbery report after a confrontation involving him and other U.S. swimmers who were in Brazil for the 2016 Olympics.
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Former Patriots Quarterback Babe Parilli Dies at 87
item.media:description: Babe Parilli, with the Jets in 1969. He had a Hall of Fame college career as a quarterback at the University of Kentucky.
item.description: Parilli, who starred in the team's American Football League days, died Saturday. He was a member of the College Football Hall of Fame.
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Three Companies, Three Facets of Balanchine’s ‘Jewels’
item.media:description: Olga Smirnova and Semyon Chudin of the Bolshoi in the “Diamonds” segment of Balanchine’s “Jewels.”
item.description: The ballerinas Dorothée Gilbert, Teresa Reichlen and Olga Smirnova talk about their roles in Lincoln Center Festival’s production of this 1967 ballet.
item.dc:creator: MARINA HARSS

item.title: Q. and A.: If Workers Are Scarce, Is It the Work or the Wages?
item.media:description: Sarah M. Smith, an owner of Rooforia Home Exteriors, at a job site in Omaha. She said hiring Americans at higher wages was unrealistic, which is why she turned to a program that gives temporary visas to guest workers to find people willing to repair roofs for $17 an hour.
item.media:credit: Ryan Henriksen for The New York Times
item.description: A roofing-business owner, turning to temporary immigrants to fill $17-an-hour jobs, says hiring Americans at better pay isn’t a realistic alternative.
item.dc:creator: PATRICIA COHEN
